awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: CAS: Tree Root Quality Inspection System with Noninvasive Evaluation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project improves the quality, value, benefits, and life span of nursery stock trees, so they will grow and thrive in the landscape where people live. Trees, with their myriad benefits for human health, ecosystem services, and climate mitigation achieve their full potential when they thrive long term. Current methods fail to adequately address tree root quality. By modernizing root inspection, this technology will not only improve industry standards and boost economic competitiveness, but also promote environmental stewardship on a global scale. With this technology, arborists and growers may be able to identify above-ground tree root defects and take corrective action to promote good quality root systems that are needed for these important tree assets to grow to maturity. 
 
This SBIR Phase I project focuses on the development of a 3-dimensional, non-destructive, ground penetrating radar (GPR) computed tomography (CT) system with cutting-edge software analytics to inspect and assess the quality of container-grown root systems in nursery stock trees. This innovation is based on the understanding that the GPR signals are generated by the large differentials between live tissues and the surrounding soil. The technology detects serious root system defects that could cause early tree mortality if not corrected before the tree is planted. The data will be collected with the help of an innovative apparatus designed to seamlessly capture 3D root data from container-grown trees using a commercial GPR system with a wireless antenna that works as a secondary layer around the container, emulating the precision of an X-ray CT scanner. A novel root quality classification model will inform the development of a root analysis software program to build an initial GPR dataset for the machine learning model and subsequently to adopt an active learning approach. Initial experiments will focus on a sufficiently large number of one or two species of trees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Nursery-grown trees develop root defects over time caused by the container's geometry, often leading to early mortality after planting. This is an unintended consequence, but it is hard to fix what you cannot see!

This project sought to demonstrate the effectiveness of ground-penetrating radar (GPR) analysis in revealing the complex features of container-grown tree root systems. Furthermore, based on our Root Quality Classification Model, we assess the feasibility of developing feature engineering and machine learning algorithms for automated evaluation. Integrating geophysics, tree biology, biomechanics, and data science significantly advances tree root quality diagnostics.

Our Team systematically reduced technical risk throughout Phase I by applying nondestructive testing methods to establish a reliable framework for evaluating root systems. Our experiments and iterative development process led to several pivotal breakthroughs, validating our approach and achieving the crucial "GO" milestone for further development.

Three key Technical Objectives outline the framework underpinning our Phase I:

  • Design and Develop a GPR Tree-CT Data Collection Gantry

We designed a lightweight, wireless, remote-controlled GPR scanning gantry inspired by medical X-ray CT technology for rapid data collection in the nursery. This tool allows growers and their customers to validate root growth pattern analyses and perform image reconstruction in containers without damaging the tree. Within a few months, we will produce our prototype for testing in collaboration with Geophysical Survey Systems Inc. (GSSI). This will mark a significant milestone in utilizing GPR for root system inspection and quality assessment.

  • Develop the Tree Root Quality Classification Model

We developed a structured quality classification model with rigorous thresholds and decision points to establish a framework for root quality grading metrics. This framework incorporates key metrics such as colonization density, lateral balance, and root branching. It provides an objective method for grading root system quality that benefits consumers (with better plant material quality) and growers (with evidence to distinguish their products). Additionally, this framework will inform our Phase II proposal, supporting corrective measure recommendations to be implemented in nursery production and at the planting site, if correctable.

  • Develop the Root-Analysis Software Algorithm(s)

We conducted experiments using constructed "phantom root" materials and live nursery stock to assess the ability to detect root density and orientation with GPR data. Across 1,186 unique scans, our experiments yielded statistically significant or highly significant results that demonstrate the potential of GPR data, combined with feature engineering and machine learning, to identify key differences in root structures. The technology accurately distinguished variations in root abundance, density, and growth patterns - establishing a foundation for automated root quality assessments. Further testing will enable algorithm training to facilitate scalable, data-driven diagnostics for evaluating tree root quality.

Technical Breakthroughs

The Innovation Lab Team at GSSI has been an invaluable partner. Their CT Filtered Back Projection (FBP) image enhancement technique for GPR has enabled the first-ever 3D representation of tree roots using this technology. This advancement paves the way for more refined analyses and commercial applications, supporting the future development of high-resolution imaging techniques for urban forestry and commercial tree production. This change can radically shift the value proposition for growing landscape trees, ensuring greater success in establishment and longer life expectancy through improved root system structure. We are progressing toward realizing INSIGHT with the shared vision that we can drive meaningful change through science, technology, persistence, and a little luck.

Our research improves Urban Forestry technology and tree risk assessment by integrating plant science, geophysics, and AI/ML-driven diagnostics. By transforming complex root morphology into actionable insights, we link research to real-world applications, making tree inspections more accurate, predictable, and accessible.

Broader Impacts

This research enhances existing green infrastructure planning, enabling municipalities and commercial growers to make data-driven decisions that improve tree longevity and ecosystem services. Furthermore, mature urban trees enhance air quality, manage stormwater, and increase climate resilience, leading to significant societal benefits. However, hidden root defects undermine these benefits, leading to tree failure, property damage, and higher maintenance costs. By providing professionals with advanced diagnostic tools, we strengthen tree preservation efforts, ensure public safety, and maximize investments in green infrastructure. This aligns with broader initiatives to build sustainable, resilient cities that benefit people and the environment.

We need trees to live.

To live, we need trees.

Beyond the lab, the NSF I-Corps experience broadened our entrepreneurial vision. While meeting with leaders and stakeholders across the Green Industry, we discussed the key question: WHO CARES?

The message was clear: our work matters! These connections are just the beginning as we form partnerships, improve our market strategy, and launch Phase II commercialization.

WE START HERE! With a solid foundation, a committed team, and a focused vision - determined to make a lasting and meaningful impact on improving the quality, value, benefits, and lifespan of the trees we grow where we live.

our bottom line

Grow Better Trees

with INSIGHT by TreesROI


Last Modified: 04/03/2025
Modified by: Marie V Ambusk
